message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The nerve that is most likely to be damaged during a radical mastectomy is the long thoracic nerve, which innervates the serratus anterior muscle. Damage to this nerve can result in winged scapula, which is manifested by scapular protrusion when pressing against a wall. Option (B) describes injury to the axillary nerve, (C) describes injury to the radial nerve, and (D) describes injury to the musculocutaneous nerve, none of which are likely to be damaged during a radical mastectomy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the nerve being nicked suggests injury to the long thoracic nerve, which supplies the serratus anterior muscle. Weakness in shoulder abduction is a typical sign of serratus anterior paralysis. Scapular protrusion while pressing against a wall is also a characteristic sign of serratus anterior paralysis, as the scapula fails to rotate properly. The other options do not involve the serratus anterior muscle or its nerve supply.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The nerve most likely to be nipped during surgery in this location is the long thoracic nerve, which supplies the serratus anterior muscle. This muscle is responsible for scapular protraction, so weakness in this muscle will lead to scapular winging and protrusion when the patient tries to press against a wall. Options B-D involve different nerves and muscle groups and are not directly related to the injury described.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the breast mass and the axillary lymph nodes suggest that surgery may damage the long thoracic nerve, leading to scapular winging and scapular protrusion when pressing against a wall. The other options are not related to the location of the nerve injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The nerve that is most likely to be injured in this scenario is the long thoracic nerve, which innervates the serratus anterior muscle that holds the scapula against the chest wall. Damage to this nerve may result in scapular winging, which is characterized by scapular protrusion while pressing against a wall. Option (B) is incorrect because weakness in shoulder abduction and numbness over the lateral shoulder are associated with injury to the axillary nerve. Option (C) is incorrect because weakness in wrist extension and numbness over the dorsal hand are associated with injury to the radial nerve. Option (D) is incorrect because weakness in arm flexion at the elbow and numbness over the lateral forearm are associated with injury to the musculocutaneous nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the affected nerve and the fact that it was nicked during the surgery suggests that it is the long thoracic nerve. This nerve innervates the serratus anterior muscle, which is required for scapular stability. Therefore, scapular protrusion while pressing against a wall is the most likely physical exam finding in this patient. Weakness in shoulder abduction and numbness over the lateral shoulder are associated with injury to the axillary nerve. Weakness in wrist extension and numbness over the dorsal hand are associated with injury to the radial nerve. Weakness in arm flexion at the elbow and numbness over the lateral forearm are associated with injury to the musculocutaneous nerve.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The nerve that is most likely to be affected by this accidental nick is the long thoracic nerve, which innervates the serratus anterior muscle. Weakness in shoulder abduction is a common sign of serratus anterior muscle paralysis. However, in this case, the patient will also likely have scapular winging, which is seen when the serratus anterior muscle is paralyzed, and the scapula is no longer anchored to the chest wall. Pressing against a wall will exaggerate this scapular winging. The other answer options describe nerves that are not likely to be affected by the accidental nick.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the breast mass and axillary lymph nodes suggests involvement of the long thoracic nerve, which supplies the serratus anterior muscle. Damage to this nerve would result in scapular winging, where the scapula protrudes away from the body when pressing against a wall. None of the other options involve this nerve or its corresponding function.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The nerve most likely to be nicked during this surgery is the long thoracic nerve, which supplies the serratus anterior muscle. Weakness in shoulder abduction and winging of the scapula are characteristic of a long thoracic nerve injury, but among the options provided, only scapular protrusion is indicative of this injury. Weakness in wrist extension and numbness over the dorsal hand are indicative of a radial nerve injury, while weakness in arm flexion at the elbow and numbness over the lateral forearm are indicative of a musculocutaneous nerve injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The location of the mass and the lymph nodes suggest that the nerve that was nicked is the long thoracic nerve, which innervates the serratus anterior muscle. Weakness in shoulder abduction and numbness over the lateral shoulder are classic signs of a long thoracic nerve injury. However, scapular protrusion while pressing against a wall is often present in cases of long thoracic nerve injury as well.
